Hi Ken, 

I made the eye static as you suggested in one previous disscussio=
n 
about this experiment, using HyperNEAT for visual recognition. 
(Roving =
eye & HyperNEAT is an overkill). It is "alive" for about 5 
timesteps, in o=
rder to use some reccurence. 

I think about the rotation.. So, let's clear=
 things out. 
A point (X,Y) is rotated with angle (Aplha) to (X1, Y1).  
Th=
is is a function, taking 3 arguments and returning 2. 

x1=3D y*sin(alpha) =
+ x*cos(alpha)
y1=3D y*cos(alpha) - x*sin(alpha)

I think this cannot be co=
vered by a single neuron, but a cluster of 
neurons with sin() and cos() ac=
tivation functions.. Am I right? 
Let's say that we have 2 inputs (x, y) an=
d a bias node in the CPPN. 
Further, we have 2 hidden nodes, one is "sine" =
other is "cosine". 
These hidden nodes are both connected to the bias. The =
bias here is 
our "alpha" value. 
Then, we can imagine how these nodes shou=
ld be connected to construct 
this formula above. We need linear outputs, a=
nd maybe some additional 
linear nodes with multiplying summing functions (=
to represent the 
multiplications by x and y)... 

Similar, translation can=
 be handled even easier. The main coordinate 
frames has to be connected to=
 2 linear nodes, where an addition to a 
bias occurs in each. 

Scaling is =
in fact everywhere, since the weights of the connections 
can be thought of=
 as scalars of the coordinate frames. 

So, that were the 3 main transforma=
tions.. :) 
But the rotation seems hard to evolve.. And using linear nodes =
and 
multiplying summing functions (before the activation) is important.

P=
eter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
=
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@> 
> =
wrote:
> > - My current experiments with ActiveVision show that it is hard =

to 
> > evolve substrates that recognize simple shapes that are randomly 
=
> > rotated. Perhaps I should tweak the NEAT parameters or the set of 
> > =
activation functions? 
> > 
> 
> Peter, in the experiment you are describin=
g, are you using a roving 
eye 
> or just inputting a whole image into the =
substrate?  With 
HyperNEAT, it 
> should be possible to do recognition tas=
ks without needing a roving 
eye.
> 
> In any case, I believe rotational in=
variance is indeed an 
activation 
> function issue.  The problem is that y=
ou need to get the same 
pattern 
> of connects repeated in a rotating fash=
ion, so that they can 
recognize 
> rotated images.  This kind of rotation =
is not a very natural 
byproduct 
> of the usual set of activation function=
s.  I believe there is 
probably 
> a rotational activation function that w=
ould be quite helpful, but I 
> have not resolved what function that should=
 be.
> 
> ken
>
